regulatoryPractice.title: Regulatory Practice vs Written Law
regulatoryPractice.subtitle: Understanding what's actually enforced in Nordic hotel renovations
regulatoryPractice.description: A practical guide to the gap between written regulations and enforcement reality. Based on industry consultations and project experience.

enforcementLevels.writtenRequirement: All wall/ceiling surfaces in hotels must meet B-s1,d0
enforcementLevels.enforcementDescription: Strictly enforced - Fire authority inspects. Project stoppage without compliance.
enforcementLevels.practicalNotes: Limited flexibility via analytisk dimensionering (performance-based design). Standard path: test or get certified materials.

enforcementLevels.writtenRequirement: Upholstered furniture in public areas must meet EN 1021-1 minimum
enforcementLevels.enforcementDescription: Insurance-driven more than authority-driven. Insurers may require documentation.
enforcementLevels.practicalNotes: Many hotels operate with mixed compliance. Insurance is the real enforcer.
enforcementLevels.riskIfIgnored: Potential insurance premium increase or coverage issues (varies by insurer)
enforcementLevels.fyraRecommendation: Prioritize high-traffic public areas. Guest rooms less scrutinized.

enforcementLevels.writtenRequirement: Building permit required for structural changes, facade changes, use changes
enforcementLevels.enforcementDescription: Required for structural work. Interior FF&E rarely requires permit.
enforcementLevels.practicalNotes: Pure interior renovation (furniture, finishes) typically permit-exempt. Verify scope doesn't include structural or use changes.
enforcementLevels.riskIfIgnored: Municipal enforcement if structural work discovered
enforcementLevels.fyraRecommendation: Interior-only projects can often proceed without permit. Verify scope.

enforcementLevels.writtenRequirement: Public buildings must be accessible. Hotels need accessible rooms.
enforcementLevels.enforcementDescription: Checked at building permit stage. Less scrutiny for interior updates.
enforcementLevels.practicalNotes: Existing hotels grandfathered unless major renovation triggers BBR 3:5 upgrade requirements (use change, major structural work, or permit-triggering scope).
enforcementLevels.fyraRecommendation: Check if renovation scope triggers accessibility upgrade requirements.

enforcementLevels.writtenRequirement: Construction products must have CE marking and DoP
enforcementLevels.enforcementDescription: Rarely checked for furniture/loose items. More relevant for fixed installations.
enforcementLevels.practicalNotes: Furniture typically not CE-marked unless built-in. Focus on fire certs instead.
enforcementLevels.fyraRecommendation: CE marking less relevant than fire certification for FF&E.

enforcementLevels.writtenRequirement: No legal requirement, but increasingly expected in public procurement
enforcementLevels.enforcementDescription: Currently voluntary. Growing expectation from ESG-focused clients.
enforcementLevels.practicalNotes: Private hotels rarely require. Public sector projects increasingly demand.
enforcementLevels.riskIfIgnored: May lose competitive advantage in ESG-sensitive projects
enforcementLevels.fyraRecommendation: Nice-to-have. Focus on fire compliance first.

enforcementLevels.writtenRequirement: Digital product passports required by 2027 for some product categories
enforcementLevels.enforcementDescription: Not yet enforced. Regulations being developed.
enforcementLevels.practicalNotes: Prepare documentation now for future requirements. Early adopter advantage.
enforcementLevels.riskIfIgnored: None currently. Strategic disadvantage as requirements emerge
enforcementLevels.fyraRecommendation: Start building material passport capability now.

interiorRenovation.title: Interior Renovation Pathway
interiorRenovation.subtitle: Lower-burden approach for FF&E updates
interiorRenovation.description: Interior-only renovations (furniture, finishes, equipment) typically avoid building permit requirements and have simplified compliance paths.

advantages.title: No Building Permit Required
advantages.description: Pure interior changes (furniture, finishes, non-structural elements) typically don't trigger building permit requirements
advantages.savings: 6-12 weeks and 50,000-150,000 SEK in permit process

advantages.title: No Accessibility Upgrade Trigger
advantages.description: Interior-only work doesn't trigger mandatory accessibility improvements required for major renovations

advantages.title: Existing Fire Systems Sufficient
advantages.description: If building's sprinklers, alarms, and compartmentation are current, furniture swap doesn't require system updates

advantages.title: Simplified Insurance Process
advantages.description: Furniture updates with fire certification typically only require insurer notification, not re-underwriting

included: Furniture replacement (beds, chairs, sofas, tables, desks)
Lighting fixtures (if not touching electrical infrastructure)
Flooring overlay (if not affecting floor levels)
excluded: MEP system modifications (plumbing, HVAC, electrical mains)
Change of use (e.g., office to hotel)
grayArea: Kitchen equipment replacement - depends on ventilation impact
Bathroom fixture replacement - OK if no plumbing changes
Door replacement - OK if fire rating maintained
Electrical outlet addition - minor works, varies by municipality

complianceChecklist.action: Document that no structural, facade, or MEP changes planned
Obtain EN 1021-1/2 test reports or manufacturer certifications
Verify any new wall coverings meet B-s1,d0 if in escape routes
Send project summary and fire certification plan to insurer
Review lease terms for landlord approval requirements
Keep records of sourcing for warranty and future resale
